author: S Harpal Singh
text:
An NoC has been issued for a stone crusher-cum-hot mix plant 200 metres from the waterfall.— Photo: S. Harpal Singh

An upcoming stone crusher-cum-hot mix plant located 200 metres away from the pristine Pochera waterfalls in Adilabad district of Telangana threatens to engulf the nature's wonder as well as the wild fauna in its vicinity.

The Revenue Department recently issued a no-objection certificate (NoC) to facilitate installation and operation of the highly-polluting stone crushing machinery and tar mixing unit. This was possible because the land located immediately next to the spot where the water falls is Revenue land.

The issue of NoC has the potential of opening flood gates for other players to arrive here, as the Pochera stream bed and the hillocks closeby have enormous deposits of black Deccan trap rock, used in the construction sector. “It is more a question of propriety than legality,” observed Giridhar Deshpande of the Kuntala Samrakshana Samiti. “Even if legal, the activity will result in noise and dust pollution, which will have a tremendous impact on the wildlife here, with the deer and monkeys nowhere to go,” he said on Wednesday.

A part of the stream and the huge pond at the foot of the waterfall are the only two watering holes within a few kilometres radius. The large population of wild ungulates, black buck, spotted deer and nilgais come to these spots to quench their thirst at night.

““Two of these scared animals, which had entered our village, were killed by poachers in the last 10 days,” a resident of Tejapur said.

NoC issued for setting up stone crusher-cum-hot mix plant located just 200 metres away from the pristine waterfall
title: Stone crushing unit threatens waterfall in Telangana
